statement.tex: \\ %text If \[ I = \int\frac{dx}{\sqrt{1-x^2}} = \int d\phi\], then what is \underline\text{$x$ in terms of $\phi$}? %
\\ %text Given that \[ I = \int d\phi \], what is \textbf{I } \underline\text{in terms of x}? %

reason.tex:
%text There is a \underline\text{standard result} for this integral. But let us remind ourselves how that standard result came about.
\underline\text{Hence, if \[ x = \sin\phi \]}, then % \begin{align} dx &= \cos\phi\cdot d\phi \\ \implies I &= \int\frac{dx}{\sqrt{1-x^2}} = \int\frac{\cos\phi\cdot d\phi}{\sqrt{1-\sin^2\phi}} \\ &= \int\frac{\cos\phi\cdot d\phi}{\cos\phi} = \int d\phi \end{align}
